docs.abstract: Philip Dray’s book “A Lynching at Port Jervis” unearths the history of an 1892 murder of a Black man at the hands of a white mob.
docs.snippet: Philip Dray’s book “A Lynching at Port Jervis” unearths the history of an 1892 murder of a Black man at the hands of a white mob.
docs.lead_paragraph: On June 2, 1892, a white mob seized a Black man and hanged him from the high branch of an old maple tree in Port Jervis, N.Y. Several days later, a jury took all of an hour to deliver its verdict on what had happened: “Robert Lewis came to his death in the village of Port Jervis on June 2nd by being hanged by his neck by a person or persons unknown.”

headline.main: When Jim Crow Violence Came to a Small New York Village
headline.print_headline: Jim Crow Violence Close to Home

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: A Lynching at Port Jervis: Race and Reckoning in the Gilded Age (Book)

docs.abstract: Passed amid protests over police brutality, the “diaphragm law” has been the target of law-enforcement unions, which say it ties officers’ hands.
docs.snippet: Passed amid protests over police brutality, the “diaphragm law” has been the target of law-enforcement unions, which say it ties officers’ hands.
docs.lead_paragraph: An appeals court reinstated a New York City law forbidding police officers from compressing a suspect’s diaphragm, the latest turn in a protracted legal struggle over the measure passed two years ago.

headline.main: Court Reinstates Ban on N.Y.P.D.’s Use of Holds That Restrict Breathing
headline.print_headline: Ban Restored on Police Use of Holds That Restrict Breathing

docs.abstract: New York’s Law Department said it dismissed the lawyer after discovering she had made a misrepresentation in court filings.
docs.snippet: New York’s Law Department said it dismissed the lawyer after discovering she had made a misrepresentation in court filings.
docs.lead_paragraph: Demonstrations in New York after the 2020 murder of George Floyd by a Minneapolis police officer led to a wave of lawsuits accusing the police of using excessive force and other abusive tactics that violated protesters’ rights.

headline.main: N.Y.C. Lawyer Fired Over Handling of George Floyd Protesters’ Lawsuits
headline.print_headline: City Fires Lawyer Who Handled Suits Tied to Protests

docs.abstract: Three new story collections explore the vagaries of daily struggles.
docs.snippet: Three new story collections explore the vagaries of daily struggles.
docs.lead_paragraph: Leigh Newman finds in her native Alaska all that she needs to survey themes of betrayal and isolation, of desertion and disintegration (physical, psychological, spiritual). In her story collection NOBODY GETS OUT ALIVE (Scribner, 278 pp., $26), the heroic loom of the mountains — “contented giants, their faces slashed with ice and moonlight” — gives way to the splintered souls — “ailing, bewildered, clouded with regret” — who prowl the foothills below. A pair of sisters, crushed by their parents’ divorce and alcoholism, turn their pain on each other, riding a “diseased seesaw” of commitment and rejection. In “Slide and Glide,” a man attempts to save his marriage by compelling his family to undertake a risky wilderness trek, seeking “something more than love — trust.” And a California newcomer, convinced of the palliative “dazzle of Alaska,” discovers that “nothing here is fixed, nothing is any better. Where is there left to go, except out of your mind?”

headline.main: Stories of Survival, in the Wilds, in Cities and at Home

docs.abstract: With a new production of Anthony Davis’s pathbreaking Malcolm X opera opening in Detroit, we are on the cusp of a broader reappraisal of his work.
docs.snippet: With a new production of Anthony Davis’s pathbreaking Malcolm X opera opening in Detroit, we are on the cusp of a broader reappraisal of his work.
docs.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — As the orchestra of the Detroit Opera tuned itself for a recent rehearsal, the outline of a vast spacecraft loomed over the pit.

headline.main: ‘It’s Anthony’s Time’: A Composer Gets His Due

keywords.value: X: The Life and Times of Malcolm X (Opera)

docs.abstract: In the neighborhood where the Tops attack took place, residents said racism has shaped their everyday lives long before the gunfire on Saturday.
docs.snippet: In the neighborhood where the Tops attack took place, residents said racism has shaped their everyday lives long before the gunfire on Saturday.
docs.lead_paragraph: They rallied at a Black Lives Matter demonstration on the concrete steps of a local park, calling for politicians to direct more resources to Buffalo’s Black residents living on the largely impoverished East Side.

headline.main: ‘Nobody Cares About Us Here’: Anguish and Anger on Buffalo’s East Side
headline.print_headline: Residents Describe  A Pattern of Racism:  ‘Pain Is in Our DNA’

docs.abstract: Francia Márquez could soon be Colombia’s first Black vice president, and she has cracked open a discussion about race and class in a manner rarely seen in national politics.
docs.snippet: Francia Márquez could soon be Colombia’s first Black vice president, and she has cracked open a discussion about race and class in a manner rarely seen in national politics.
docs.lead_paragraph: CALI, Colombia — In the streets of Cali, a cradle of Colombian culture and protest, a crowd stretched for blocks, flying white campaign flags and wearing T-shirts that read “the people will not surrender!”

headline.main: Teen Mother. Housekeeper. Activist. Vice President?
headline.print_headline: Poised to Shatter Ceilings in Colombian Politics

docs.abstract: The author Nina LaCour is known for her young adult novels. She is making her adult debut with a tale of two women finding themselves, and each other.
docs.snippet: The author Nina LaCour is known for her young adult novels. She is making her adult debut with a tale of two women finding themselves, and each other.
docs.lead_paragraph: When Sara, one of the protagonists in “Yerba Buena,” was a girl, she and her family used to play a game. They started with a blank piece of paper. Each person in turn would begin to sketch, slowly building the scene. As Sara and her brother watched, “their father moved his pencil, faint lines that turned — as if by magic — into places and things they recognized.” Suddenly, there it was: an entire world, familiar yet strange, and within it, a story.

headline.main: Love and Trauma in the Wilds of California

docs.abstract: Emily Weiss, the founder of Glossier and a face on the Mount Rushmore of start-up culture, will no longer be the beauty company’s chief executive.
docs.snippet: Emily Weiss, the founder of Glossier and a face on the Mount Rushmore of start-up culture, will no longer be the beauty company’s chief executive.
docs.lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, Emily Weiss, the chief executive of Glossier Inc., announced that she would be stepping down from the top role at the skin care and beauty brand she founded in 2014. Glossier broke with many industry conventions to become an e-commerce darling promising millennial consumers nonchalant, woke-up-like-this dewy skin in pastel shades. Ms. Weiss’s own stylish, fresh-faced image — on Instagram, in interviews — was an inextricable part of the brand.

headline.main: The Sunsetting of the Girlboss Is Nearly Complete
